## Start by plotting some random

Let's start with a regular R plot. Plot `y` by `x`. Before we can plot `x` and `y` we need an `x` and a `y` to plot! Below makes some random data using the `runif()` function.

`runif` (short for "random uniform") pulls random values from a ["uniform" distribution](https://www.statisticshowto.com/probability-and-statistics/statistics-definitions/uniform-distribution/) (uniform here means that all values are equally likely, the probability of each value is uniform).

## Modifying axes

It's snowing!!

<center><img src="https://i.imgur.com/94n8qwl.png" width="50%"/></center>

Get them pesky axes out of there....

P.S. its very rare for someone to know all of these plot options - they look overwhelming because, well, they are. Good news, R often chooses reasonable defaults, and in almost every real charting scenario, removing the axes is a horrible idea.

```{r}
par(pty = "s")
plot(
  x,
  y,
  asp = 1, # aspect ratio
  xlab = "", # no x axis label
  ylab = "", # no y axis label
  yaxt = "n",
  axes = FALSE, # turn off axes
  frame.plot = TRUE, # turn of the outline around the plot
)
```

Let's manually control the axes limits so that the snow isn't so close to the bottom of the frame.

```{r}
par(pty = "s")
plot(
  x,
  y,
  asp = 1,
  xlim = c(0, 10),
  ylim = c(0, 10),
  xlab = "", # no x axis label
  ylab = "", # no y axis label
  axes = FALSE, # turn off axes
  frame.plot = TRUE, # turn of the outline around the plot
)
```

Hmmmm.... bummer.... R creates a new canvas everytime we call the `plot()` function.

So to combine this beautimus hill and our snow we can't use `plot()`. We have two separate sets of `x`s & `y`s to draw and if we use `plot()` twice it will make two separate pictures. We can use `lines()` to draw our hill after we use `plot()` to create our canvas and draw the snow.

```{r}

y <- runif(32, 3, 10)

  x,

  xlim = c(1, 9),
  ylim = c(0, 9),

  xlab = "", # no x axis label

  frame.plot = TRUE, # turn of the outline around the plot
)

y <- -0.04 * (x - 4)^2 + 2

lines(x, y)
```

## Snowflakes should be different sizes

What would make it look more like snow?...

Snowflakes shouldn't all be the same size. What's beautiful about nature is the irregularities.

First lets just look at how to modify the size of the points.

------------------------------------------------------------------------

*ðŸš¨ Pause ðŸš¨: we are mature professionals that can acknowledge homophones and push forward? ... right?*

------------------------------------------------------------------------

The `cex` parameter of `plot()` stands for "character expansion". It is how we can set the percent size of points or text in base R plots. By default it is set to 1 (100%) but if you want points twice as big set it to 2 (200%) and if you want points half as big set it to 0.5 (50%).

```{r}
par(pty = "s")

x <- runif(32, 0, 10)
y <- runif(32, 3, 10)

plot(x,
  y,
  cex = 0.4,
  asp = 1,
  xlim = c(0, 10),
  ylim = c(0, 10),
  xlab = "", # no x axis label
  ylab = "", # no y axis label
  axes = FALSE, # turn off axes
  frame.plot = TRUE, # turn of the outline around the plot
)
```

With a function we can make our morning routine easier to repeat

```{r}
morning_routine <- function(day) {
  print(paste("--- Day", day, "------------"))
  print("brush teeth")
  print("take shower")
  print("apply deodorant")
  print("put in contacts")
  print("get dressed")
  print("do hair")
  print("make coffee")
  print("----------------------")
}
```

```{r}
# Day 1
morning_routine(day = 1)

# Day 2
morning_routine(day = 2)

# Day 3
morning_routine(day = 3)
```

We can add "parameters" aka "arguments" to change up the routine if we need to

```{r}
morning_routine <- function(day, in_a_rush = FALSE) {
  print(paste("--- Day", day, "------------"))
  print("brush teeth")

  if (!in_a_rush) print("take shower")

  print("apply deodorant")
  print("put in contacts")

  if (!in_a_rush) {
    print("get dressed")
  } else {
    print("sweat pants")
  }

  if (!in_a_rush) {
    print("do hair")
    print("make coffee")
  }

  print("----------------------")
}
```

```{r}
morning_routine(day = 1, in_a_rush = FALSE)
morning_routine(day = 2, in_a_rush = TRUE)
```

```{r}
my_summary <- function(x) {

    cat("X is character data\n\n")

  cat("\nProportion of X that's NA:\n")
  print(mean(is.na(x)))
}
```

Back to our snowscape arting:

This function will take our `x`, `y`, `cex` and plot them just like we've been doing. The addition I made was the use of `points()`, like `lines()` this lets us draw to an existing canvas rather than creating a new plot.

```{r}
plot_snow <- function(x, y, cex = 1, new_plot = TRUE, ...) {
  if (new_plot) {
    par(pty = "s")
    plot(
      x,
      y,
      asp = 1,
      cex = cex,
      xlim = c(0, 10),
      ylim = c(0, 10),
      xlab = "", # no x axis label
      ylab = "", # no y axis label
      axes = FALSE, # turn off axes
      frame.plot = TRUE, # turn of the outline around the plot
      ...
    )
  } else {
    points(x, y, cex = cex)
  }
}
```

Use the function to plot 2 different sizes of snow to the same picture.

```{r}
x <- runif(n = 10, min = 0, max = 10)
y <- runif(n = 10, min = 4, max = 10)
plot_snow(x, y, cex = 0.8, new_plot = TRUE)

x <- runif(n = 10, min = 0, max = 10)
y <- runif(n = 10, min = 4, max = 10)
plot_snow(x, y, cex = 0.3, new_plot = FALSE)
```

```{r}
blank_canvas <- function(xlim = c(0, 10),
                         ylim = c(0, 10)) {
  par(pty = "s")
  plot(

    asp = 1, type = "n",
    xlim = xlim, ylim = ylim,
    xlab = "", ylab = "",
    axes = FALSE, frame.plot = TRUE

blank_canvas()
```

Functionalize!

Practice "parameterizing" by adding a parameter to control the percent size of head to body.

```{r}
snowman <- function(base_r = 2, base_x = 5, base_y = 2) {
  draw.circle(base_x, base_y, base_r)

  head_r <- base_r * 0.6
  head_y <- base_y + base_r + head_r
  draw.circle(base_x, head_y, head_r)
}

blank_canvas()
snowman()

blank_canvas()
snowman(base_r = 3, base_x = 3, base_y = 2)
```

What's a couple more circles, add some eyes.

```{r}
snowman <- function(base_r = 2, base_x = 5, base_y = 2) {
  draw.circle(base_x, base_y, base_r)

  head_r <- base_r * 0.6
  head_y <- base_y + base_r + head_r
  draw.circle(base_x, head_y, head_r)

  eyes_dx <- head_r * 0.25
  eyes_y <- head_y + head_r * 0.2
  eyes_r <- head_r * 0.1

  draw.circle(base_x - eyes_dx, eyes_y, eyes_r)
  draw.circle(base_x + eyes_dx, eyes_y, eyes_r)
}

blank_canvas()
snowman()
```

Arms and then I'm done.

```{r}
snowman <- function(base_r = 2, base_x = 5, base_y = 2) {
  # tush
  draw.circle(base_x, base_y, base_r)

  # noggin
  head_r <- base_r * 0.6
  head_y <- base_y + base_r + head_r
  draw.circle(base_x, head_y, head_r)

  # peepers
  eyes_dx <- head_r * 0.25
  eyes_y <- head_y + head_r * 0.2
  eyes_r <- head_r * 0.1
  draw.circle(base_x - eyes_dx, eyes_y, eyes_r)
  draw.circle(base_x + eyes_dx, eyes_y, eyes_r)

  # guns
  arms_dx1 <- base_r * 0.8
  arms_dx2 <- base_r * 0.5
  arms_y1 <- base_y + base_r * 0.5
  arms_y2 <- base_y + base_r

  right_arm_xs <- c(base_x + arms_dx1, base_x + arms_dx1 + arms_dx2)
  left_arm_xs <- c(base_x - arms_dx1, base_x - arms_dx1 - arms_dx2)
  arm_ys <- c(arms_y1, arms_y2)
  lines(right_arm_xs, arm_ys)
  lines(left_arm_xs, arm_ys)
}

blank_canvas()
snowman()
```

Well isn't that just the cutest darn snowman you've ever plotted

## More functions!

```{r}
snow <- function(sizes = seq(from = 0.05, to = 1, by = 0.025)) {
  new_plot <- TRUE
  for (size in sizes) {
    n_flakes <- round(runif(1, 2, 6))
    x <- runif(n = n_flakes, min = -1, max = 11)
    y <- runif(n = n_flakes, min = 3, max = 11)
    plot_snow(x, y, cex = size, new_plot = new_plot)
    new_plot <- FALSE
  }
}

hill <- function() {
  x <- -1:11
  y <- -0.04 * (x - 4)^2 + 2

  lines(x, y)
}
```

## Fun with word clouds

Scrape some data. I chose https://www.41051.com/xmaslyrics/ because it popped up first on my google search

```{r include=FALSE}
# site's going to change or block me...
# reading from google sheets
carol_lyrics_df <- read.csv("https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1kNleoC8w0yVt0KU2tqAfNqPdUHNuWsZat4Q_d_UE6Tc/export?format=csv")
```

```{r eval=FALSE}
base_site <- "https://www.41051.com/xmaslyrics/"

# download base site
response <- httr::GET(base_site)
stop_for_status(response)

# pull the address from each carol's link
links <- response |>
  content() |>
  html_nodes("#p7HMY_2 a") |>
  html_attr("href")

# get the lyrics from each carol's page
carol_lyrics <- vapply(links, function(link) {
  # example: https://www.41051.com/xmaslyrics/chestnuts.html
  lyrics_url <- paste0(base_site, link)

  # download lyrics page
  response <- httr::GET(lyrics_url)
  stop_for_status(response)

  # pull lyrics from page a remove lead/trail whitespace
  response |>
    content() |>
    html_nodes("div.hmy-left p") |>
    html_text() |>
    trimws()
}, character(1))

# remove google ads stuff and clean up whitespace
carol_lyrics <- carol_lyrics |>
  gsub(
    pattern = "(adsbygoogle = window.adsbygoogle || []).push({});",
    replacement = "",
    fixed = TRUE
  ) |>
  gsub(pattern = "\\s{2,}", replacement = "\n")

# store in data.frame and write to file
carol_lyrics_df <- data.frame(
  id = gsub(links, pattern = ".html", replacement = ""),
  source = paste0(base_site, links),
  lyrics = carol_lyrics
)

write.csv(carol_lyrics_df, "xmas_carols.csv", row.names = FALSE)
```

